cards.front: What is **uniform circular motion**?
cards.back: The motion of an object traveling at a constant speed in a circular path.

cards.front: What is **tangential velocity**?
cards.back: The velocity of an object at any point in its circular path, which is always tangent to the circle.

cards.front: In uniform circular motion, is velocity constant?
cards.back: No. The speed is constant, but the velocity is always changing direction.

What is the **centripetal force**?
cards.back: The net force that causes an object to move in a circular path. It is always directed toward the center of the circle.

What is **centripetal acceleration**?
cards.back: The acceleration of an object moving in a circle, always directed toward the center.

What is **centrifugal force**?
cards.back: A fictitious force that appears to push an object away from the center of a circular path. It is not a real force.

cards.front: What is the difference between centripetal and centrifugal force?
cards.back: Centripetal force is a real force directed inward, while centrifugal force is an apparent force directed outward due to inertia.

cards.front: What is the **period (T)** of circular motion?
cards.back: The time it takes for an object to complete one full revolution.

cards.front: What is the SI unit for period?
What is the **frequency (f)** of circular motion?
cards.back: The number of revolutions per unit of time.

cards.back: Friction between the tires and the road.

At the top of a vertical circle, what two forces provide the centripetal force?
cards.back: Tension (or Normal Force) and the force of gravity (weight).

cards.front: At the bottom of a vertical circle, what two forces provide the centripetal force?
cards.back: Tension (or Normal Force) minus the force of gravity (weight).

cards.front: What is the minimum speed needed for an object to complete a vertical loop?
cards.back: The speed at the top where tension is zero.

Why do passengers in a car feel pushed outward when turning a corner?
cards.back: Their inertia causes them to want to continue in a straight line, while the car turns.

cards.front: What happens to an object's path if the centripetal force suddenly vanishes?
cards.back: It will fly off in a straight line tangent to the circular path.

cards.front: Why are banked curves used on racetracks and highways?
cards.back: To use a component of the normal force to provide the necessary centripetal force.

cards.front: What is the relationship between the radius of a turn and the centripetal force required?
cards.back: The force is inversely proportional to the radius.

cards.front: What is the angular velocity of an object in circular motion?
cards.back: The rate of change of the angle, measured in radians per second.
